title: Cecil Tyndale-Biscoe
text:
Cecil Earle Tyndale-Biscoe (9 February 1863 – 1 August 1949) was a British <a href="missionary">missionary</a> and <a href="educationist">educationist</a>, who worked in <a href="Kashmir">Kashmir</a> where he established the <a href="Tyndale%20Biscoe%20School">Tyndale Biscoe School</a>. He was born with the family name Biscoe. It was changed to Tyndale-Biscoe in 1883.
Life.
Biscoe was born at <a href="Holton%2C%20Oxfordshire">Holton</a> near <a href="Oxford">Oxford</a>, England, into a land-owning family, the son of William Earle Biscoe and his wife Elizabeth Carey Sandeman. He was educated at <a href="Bradfield%20College">Bradfield College</a>, and then <a href="Jesus%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Jesus College, Cambridge</a>. At university he <a href="Coxswain%20%28rowing%29">coxed</a> the winning <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Boat%20Club">Cambridge</a> crew in the 1884 <a href="Boat%20Race">Boat Race</a>. In 1885 he coxed the winning <a href="Jesus%20College%20Boat%20Club%20%28Cambridge%29">Jesus College</a> crew in the <a href="Grand%20Challenge%20Cup">Grand Challenge Cup</a> at <a href="Henley%20Royal%20Regatta">Henley Royal Regatta</a>. After being awarded a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Arts">BA</a>, he was ordained as a priest of the <a href="Church%20of%20England">Church of England</a>. After a short time working in London's <a href="Whitechapel">East End</a>, in 1890 Tyndale-Biscoe was appointed to a missionary school in Kashmir by the <a href="Church%20Missionary%20Society">Church Missionary Society</a>.
Tyndale-Biscoe married Blanche Violet Burges, daughter of Reverend Richard B. Burges, on 2 November 1891 and had four children. When <a href="Irene%20Petrie">Irene Petrie</a> joined the mission she stayed with them at Holton Cottage.
In the late 19th century, Kashmir was a <a href="princely%20state">princely state</a> made up of a <a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> majority ruled by a <a href="Maharaja">Maharaja</a> and his <a href="Hindu">Hindu</a> minority. The Maharaja often utilized the services of British and European experts, though Kashmir was an independent kingdom. Seeing the squalid conditions and <a href="caste%20system">caste system</a> as a serious problem, Tyndale-Biscoe aimed to use his own <a href="Christian%20values">Christian values</a> and <a href="Western%20world">western</a> civic ideals to improve Kashmiri society. Although he did not actively pursue conversions as much as his missionary backers would have liked, Tyndale-Biscoe was a convinced <a href="imperialist">imperialist</a> and supporter of the <a href="India%20Defence%20League">India Defence League</a>.
Tyndale-Biscoe's educational philosophy was one in which conspicuous intellect, or "cleverness", was valued less than the acquisition of more profound attributes and abilities. His schooling placed emphasis on physical activities – <a href="boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="boating">boating</a>, <a href="Association%20football">football</a> – which would stimulate senses of <a href="courage">courage</a>, <a href="masculinity">masculinity</a> and <a href="physical%20fitness">physical fitness</a>. The pupils were also engaged in civic duties, such as street-cleaning, and in helping deal with <a href="flooding">flooding</a> and <a href="cholera">cholera</a>. Enforcing participation in team sports and activities in a highly socially stratified culture had significance beyond the replication of Tyndale-Biscoe's <a href="English%20public%20school">English public school</a> educational experience.
By his later years, Tyndale-Biscoe had founded six schools with 1,800 students. In 1912 he received the <a href="Kaisar-I-Hind%20Medal">Kaisar-I-Hind Medal</a>, and an additional bar in 1929. After <a href="Partition%20of%20India">Indian independence</a>, he left for what was then known as <a href="Southern%20Rhodesia">Southern Rhodesia</a>, where he died in 1949.
